The line of morality is sometimes very
fancifully drawn. A municipal law of
Georgetown, S. Z. declares to play billiards
after il O'Clock at night, is dangerous to NOR
ais. but playing before twelve o'clock is
nroper and legal If a game therefore is be-
gun a few minutes before twelve and ended
few minutes after twelve, the first part IS
correct and proper, but the latter part dam
nable and corrupt. When the clock desig-
mates between vice and virtue, clock makers
are the greatest philosophers.


An Irishman by the name OF john Mullen, was
killed in Brooklyn on the Goth "lt by blow on
the head. from one of the arms OF a windmill
near Mitchell S oil factory.


The Patterson On. J. ln'ellgcncer states
that a man aged lO4 years, came to that place
last week from New-York on foot, distance of l6
miles to obtain employment. lie IS native OF
Scotland. -


We learn from Mexico, that on the 25d OF
February the monk .Rrenos, whose plot against
the government we had occasion to mention
some time ago, was condemned to death, by
the military court. In the following week he
was to be shot.

Pacific, have received their wages, and. ac
cording to the papers Of that city, are enjoy
ing themselves after their own fashion,
They are seen dashing through the streets


10 carriages, at the rate of ten Knots and
are to be found at all the public places of
amusement, equipped in their naval costume,
such as a tarpaulin hat, Gan indispensable
head dress to son of Neptune, blue round
about jacket. and blue shirt collars. There
is perhaps no race of mankind who take the


world and its cares easier than these hardy
fellows. When at sea, their wants are pro-


yided for, and no care disturbs the tranqulli-


ty Of their feelings. "In rain and sunshine, in


calm and tempest, the same unclouded
| brow bespeaks the unruilled state ~ all


within; the watch below succeeds the watch
on deck; pleasant weather must succeed the


storm, and these are the only alterations that


occur to break the general monotony OF


their life. The hour of serving grog, until
i, arrives, affords something to wish tor;-


when it is past, they collect in messes a


round their kids and cans; and their iowly
fare IS cnioyed with a better relish, keen
or annette, and lighter heart, than often


belong to the guests at the rich mans table"


Omen, frank and candid, sailor treats
the world as though all mankind were as
honest as himself. When on shore, they
, love to recount their perils at sea. and when
again assembled on the forecastlc, they have


many hearty laugh at their adventures
2 while on shore. Money. to them, is thing
of little value, aud sailor will seldom or


ever take dollar with him when bound up
} on his tavoritc clement; he "liyes while he
: l;vcs''--the world and its cares he is free
: from; snug ship and a fan breeze is his


delight, and he does not care to what quar-
{ ter of the world he maybe bound.


n Among all the inventions which have beer
$. conceived by the ingenuity of man, for the
9 promotion OF happiness in physical or mo-
y raj point of view, there is none likely te
|. produce so ncaculable benefit to indvid

e as that lately invented by DR.. Chambers. o

in a French physician, Of New Orleans, which
II has the astonishing effect of SuhErcSSiag in
OF temher ance.

inant vice, is presented to the public in tn
id shape of powders, and to be taken nike
lie with liquor of that kind most liked 10y tn
y drinker. 1t has been administered to man
>. confirmed drunkards of the city of New
ID York, and has not yet (and we hope neye

ical change in the life of the patient. 1h

in visiting individuals and families in New
of York for the express purpose of ascertain
IN ing the truth of previous statements, and

ne Mr. S. respectable mechanic, well know

the medicine, and has restored him suce.

RIOTOUS.-The Firemen or boys of
Philadelphia, have been scufflng in the
neighborhood of their Engines. The Demo-
cratic Press says, "Several had their clothes
torn, and some we're injured. One young
man, we take shame to our quiet city. whe'
we mention it, had the first joint of the fore
finger of his right hand bit off. 1t was for
merly the practice for the High Constables
to be seen perambuating our streets with
their maces in their hands. Would it not bt
well to revive that ancient custom."

chasers. Flour was retailing at Eve aud half

~''''''
says he is willing to proclaim to the world the


benefit he has received from DR.. Chambers.


Mr. A. ayoung man thirty years of age, has


been dreadfully intemperate thirteen years. His


father, who is now dead, was the same, and


brought up his son in his own habts.--1his
young man has been twice lunatic; three times
brought to the gates of death by fits; ten times
| committed to the watch house; and repeatedly


brought home drunk to his mother, who is
widow, all in consequence OF intemperance. lie
took the medicine seven weeks ago last Friday,


and continued to take it till the Tuesday follow


ing, and he has had no desire of spirituous IL
! quors since The facts in this we collected
from his mother, his employer and himself.


have seldom seen more grateful and happy wo-


man than his mother.


| lntemperance is the predominant vice OF


this country, and may be looked upon as the


mother OF almost all other vices. The public


calamities which have been caused by it are


great. and those ofd private nature are without


number. It has been the cause Of destroying


the domestic happiness of more families than


any other whatever. 1t has destroyed more


human lives in this country than any other dis


ease; and, averaging them, it will be found


that four ffths of all the inhabitants of our
poor-houses, jails, and penitentaries, are its
victims--tracc their miserable condition to its


cause, and there you will find intemherancc.


Who is there that cannot point out some


particular individual, now a miserable drum
{ ken vagabond, who was once respectable


member Of society Who is there that cannot
point out some broken-heaited mother or
wife, whose sorrow has all been caused by,a
drunken son or husbantl--and who is there
that does not know of some family which was
, once enjoying all the comforts and happiness
. that that this world is heir to, until mtem-
$ herance was marked upon the check of him
S whose care it should have been to protect
Y the destiny of his tender offspring. Let
n the following extract finish the sketch:
t "Follow him. you have heart to do it
IS as he staggers, now and then licking tht


ground, tl he reaches his once peaceful
s home-'He's coming cry the little inno-
y cents. as they look through the window; but
j. It is not the cry of joy, that welcomes kind
fl. parent, as he approaches his tender fami,
/. --ah, no! tits the cry of fear-ot horror
y See them Ace from him as from monster--
Is loo!; at the broken hearted mother, as sht
r. takes up her aHrighted boy and bathes him


with her tears. An, says she to her chill


dren, your father once loved you -once low
N ed mc--he was kind husband and PROV


dent father: but now we are forsaken; youI
: little tender feet feel the nipping frost; you'
o. bodies shver with cold; your tattered clothe!
to are falling from YOU, and have no new one
a. to give; you arc hungry, but have no breat
!, for you; the necessaries Of life your fathel
~ was once wont to bring home to cheer on
OF ncarts, are now changed Tor the ram bottle
~ which some demon had furnished him with
RI perhaps as the reward of his days labonr
!, % cruel employer come and behold thu
- fruits of your nquity; see the miseries en-


tailed upon the wrctched mother, and he
~ worseth than fathcress children, by your thirs
he for gan!"


ed Let the imagination supply the remaining
he part Of the awful picture.


nv Intemperance rs making frisht!ul progres
w. among the inhabitants of this place,---it
er not confined to the mcnial oi plebian. bu
ii. shcws itself among the higher order OF tn
HI. community-neither is it confined to the oil
"a or middle aged, but can be marked wit
of visible demonstrations upon the young.
IN anv doubt this fact, let them occasionally
,e- of any evening, step into the barrooms OF on
ne nubhc houses. and see for themselves.
W


IN The trial of Maubrieul, the individua
/ who attacked Talleyrand, as reported in tn


Courier Francais, is highly curious. In
~ prisoner defended himself, and made spi,


tied address to the tribunal. He gave q nc
=, version to many of the facts which had bee
- published. relating to his history, and accus
NJ ed Talleyrand Of having employed him t
in, assassinate Bonaparte, deed which hl
II. conscience would not allow him to do. III
m. stated that, afterwards, the minister ha
ad- done him great injury on account OF his be
of inc possessed of these facts against him, an
,us that the act of violence OF which he wa
AVS guilty. was intended more as an indgnit
rk, than personal injury He repeated twic
nd that he regretted that he had not spit upo
he him. When it was announced that he wa
'n- to be imprisoned for five years. he said, g


would be longer than he should live; but thu
wn it was of no consequence"

vance. 1t viii be sent to any part of the United

MARRIED.

The Sabbath, like Times angel, smiles,


And hush'd is earthly care;
And labor now may cease its tolls


And tread the course of prayer
No sound in festive hall is heard,


Nor song in lady's boweri
Peace, and her sister Silence guard


Sure! tis, the hallowed hour.
ITallowed, bnt not if idle dreams,


Still lull the slumbering thought,
Let heaven unveil its radiant beams,


The closed eye heeds them not
Or opened, dost thou grasp but earth,


Its glory, gold and power,
Its bowers OF love and haunts of mirth--


Thou hast no hallowed hour
There's nought can hallow time but when


IT'S hallowed in the breast
'Thou'rt blest-but thou must feel cen then


That heaven hath made me blest,
Or say, though grief's deep floods rush ON


And clouds OF sorrow lower,
20 God! thy will not mine, be done,'--


Then is the hallowed hour

From the ". H. Spectator,
THE HaLLOWED HOUR.

How poor, how rich, how abject, how august,
How complicate, how wonderful is man
How passing wonder he who made him such,
Who center'd in our make such strange extremes
From diti'rent nature marvellously MKT.
Connexio exquisite of distant worlds
Distinguished link in beings endless chain
Midway from nature to the Deity!


Dim miniature of greatness absolute


An heir OF glory fIail child of dust!


Helpless immortal; insect infinite!


A worm! A God! Young's Night Thoughts.

full articles.article:
RIOTOUS.-The Firemen or boys of
Philadelphia, have been scufflng in the
neighborhood of their Engines. The Demo-
cratic Press says, "Several had their clothes
torn, and some we're injured. One young
man, we take shame to our quiet city. whe'
we mention it, had the first joint of the fore
finger of his right hand bit off. 1t was for
merly the practice for the High Constables
to be seen perambuating our streets with
their maces in their hands. Would it not bt
well to revive that ancient custom."

~''''''
says he is willing to proclaim to the world the


benefit he has received from DR.. Chambers.


Mr. A. ayoung man thirty years of age, has


been dreadfully intemperate thirteen years. His


father, who is now dead, was the same, and


brought up his son in his own habts.--1his
young man has been twice lunatic; three times
brought to the gates of death by fits; ten times
| committed to the watch house; and repeatedly


brought home drunk to his mother, who is
widow, all in consequence OF intemperance. lie
took the medicine seven weeks ago last Friday,


and continued to take it till the Tuesday follow


ing, and he has had no desire of spirituous IL
! quors since The facts in this we collected
from his mother, his employer and himself.


have seldom seen more grateful and happy wo-


man than his mother.


| lntemperance is the predominant vice OF


this country, and may be looked upon as the


mother OF almost all other vices. The public


calamities which have been caused by it are


great. and those ofd private nature are without


number. It has been the cause Of destroying


the domestic happiness of more families than


any other whatever. 1t has destroyed more


human lives in this country than any other dis


ease; and, averaging them, it will be found


that four ffths of all the inhabitants of our
poor-houses, jails, and penitentaries, are its
victims--tracc their miserable condition to its


cause, and there you will find intemherancc.


Who is there that cannot point out some


particular individual, now a miserable drum
{ ken vagabond, who was once respectable


member Of society Who is there that cannot
point out some broken-heaited mother or
wife, whose sorrow has all been caused by,a
drunken son or husbantl--and who is there
that does not know of some family which was
, once enjoying all the comforts and happiness
. that that this world is heir to, until mtem-
$ herance was marked upon the check of him
S whose care it should have been to protect
Y the destiny of his tender offspring. Let
n the following extract finish the sketch:
t "Follow him. you have heart to do it
IS as he staggers, now and then licking tht


ground, tl he reaches his once peaceful
s home-'He's coming cry the little inno-
y cents. as they look through the window; but
j. It is not the cry of joy, that welcomes kind
fl. parent, as he approaches his tender fami,
/. --ah, no! tits the cry of fear-ot horror
y See them Ace from him as from monster--
Is loo!; at the broken hearted mother, as sht
r. takes up her aHrighted boy and bathes him


with her tears. An, says she to her chill


dren, your father once loved you -once low
N ed mc--he was kind husband and PROV


dent father: but now we are forsaken; youI
: little tender feet feel the nipping frost; you'
o. bodies shver with cold; your tattered clothe!
to are falling from YOU, and have no new one
a. to give; you arc hungry, but have no breat
!, for you; the necessaries Of life your fathel
~ was once wont to bring home to cheer on
OF ncarts, are now changed Tor the ram bottle
~ which some demon had furnished him with
RI perhaps as the reward of his days labonr
!, % cruel employer come and behold thu
- fruits of your nquity; see the miseries en-


tailed upon the wrctched mother, and he
~ worseth than fathcress children, by your thirs
he for gan!"


ed Let the imagination supply the remaining
he part Of the awful picture.


nv Intemperance rs making frisht!ul progres
w. among the inhabitants of this place,---it
er not confined to the mcnial oi plebian. bu
ii. shcws itself among the higher order OF tn
HI. community-neither is it confined to the oil
"a or middle aged, but can be marked wit
of visible demonstrations upon the young.
IN anv doubt this fact, let them occasionally
,e- of any evening, step into the barrooms OF on
ne nubhc houses. and see for themselves.
W


IN The trial of Maubrieul, the individua
/ who attacked Talleyrand, as reported in tn


Courier Francais, is highly curious. In
~ prisoner defended himself, and made spi,


tied address to the tribunal. He gave q nc
=, version to many of the facts which had bee
- published. relating to his history, and accus
NJ ed Talleyrand Of having employed him t
in, assassinate Bonaparte, deed which hl
II. conscience would not allow him to do. III
m. stated that, afterwards, the minister ha
ad- done him great injury on account OF his be
of inc possessed of these facts against him, an
,us that the act of violence OF which he wa
AVS guilty. was intended more as an indgnit
rk, than personal injury He repeated twic
nd that he regretted that he had not spit upo
he him. When it was announced that he wa
'n- to be imprisoned for five years. he said, g


would be longer than he should live; but thu
wn it was of no consequence"

full articles.headline:
From the ". H. Spectator,
THE HaLLOWED HOUR.
full articles.article:
The Sabbath, like Times angel, smiles,


And hush'd is earthly care;
And labor now may cease its tolls


And tread the course of prayer
No sound in festive hall is heard,


Nor song in lady's boweri
Peace, and her sister Silence guard


Sure! tis, the hallowed hour.
ITallowed, bnt not if idle dreams,


Still lull the slumbering thought,
Let heaven unveil its radiant beams,


The closed eye heeds them not
Or opened, dost thou grasp but earth,


Its glory, gold and power,
Its bowers OF love and haunts of mirth--


Thou hast no hallowed hour
There's nought can hallow time but when


IT'S hallowed in the breast
'Thou'rt blest-but thou must feel cen then


That heaven hath made me blest,
Or say, though grief's deep floods rush ON


And clouds OF sorrow lower,
20 God! thy will not mine, be done,'--


Then is the hallowed hour

How poor, how rich, how abject, how august,
How complicate, how wonderful is man
How passing wonder he who made him such,
Who center'd in our make such strange extremes
From diti'rent nature marvellously MKT.
Connexio exquisite of distant worlds
Distinguished link in beings endless chain
Midway from nature to the Deity!


Dim miniature of greatness absolute


An heir OF glory fIail child of dust!


Helpless immortal; insect infinite!


A worm! A God! Young's Night Thoughts.
